blurb: Designer John Varvatos ran the anchor leg of the New York Fashion Week: Men's and helped make its debut season a success.
title: New York Fashion Week: Men’s most valuable player, John Varvatos

items.content: New York Fashion Week: Men’s most valuable player, John Varvatos

items.blurb: Designer John Varvatos’s spring 2016 show was the anchor leg of New York Fashion Week: Men’s. (John Varvatos)
items.fullcaption: Designer John Varvatos’s spring 2016 show was the anchor leg of New York Fashion Week: Men’s. (John Varvatos)

items.content: NEW YORK — Fashion is not a sport, but it does require a team effort to succeed. And during the inaugural New York Fashion Week: Men’s, designer John Varvatos was the most valuable player.

His Thursday night fashion show served as the finale to four days of runway presentations and tableaux vivants. It was not the most provocative collection. It wasn’t even one of his strongest, as he played on mostly one note: the skinny striped suit of the British rockers who landed in California two generations ago and exerted their influence over the music scene.
The suits were skinny. The jackets were short. The pants were tight. The models had long, flowing hair or artfully mussed short locks.

items.blurb: Rock star stripes from the spring 2016 John Varvatos collection. (John Varvatos)
items.fullcaption: Rock star stripes from the spring 2016 John Varvatos collection. (John Varvatos)

items.blurb: Skinny suit, skinny stripes at the spring 2016 John Varvatos show. (John Varvatos)
items.fullcaption: Skinny suit, skinny stripes at the spring 2016 John Varvatos show. (John Varvatos)

items.content: But the show exuded importance and that’s what mattered. The blank loft space on the western edge of Soho was transformed with hundreds of black umbrellas suspended from the rafters and a runway covered in taupe and black ribbon striped fabric. Major retailers settled into front-row seats. Top editors perched on bleachers. Celebrities rolled in.

items.blurb: The usual trappings of a happening: selfies backstage at the spring 2016 John Varvatos shows. (John Varvatos)
items.fullcaption: The usual trappings of a happening: selfies backstage at the spring 2016 John Varvatos shows. (John Varvatos)

items.content: Varvatos has traditionally debuted his collection in Europe, but he shifted the entire production to New York in order to give this city’s menswear week a fashion brand with a large footprint — one that would resonate with a wide audience, including the few international editors who came in for the collections.
[Lessons from Men’s Fashion Week: Don’t worry, fellows, this won’t hurt a bit.]

American menswear has only a handful of major names that are associated with fashion — rather than athletic wear, suits or denim. Calvin Klein’s Italo Zucchelli debuted his collection in Italy as usual. In New York, the brand offered a repeat of what had already been seen — on mannequins rather than live models.

items.blurb: Calvin Klein Men’s Spring 2016 Collection. (Calvin Klein Collection)
items.fullcaption: Calvin Klein Men’s Spring 2016 Collection. (Calvin Klein Collection)

items.content: Ralph Lauren showed his Polo division at the company’s Madison Avenue offices — a world away from the hub of the men’s shows. For spring, Polo is focused on a softer jacket shoulder, bracing colors and a broader range of performance sportswear as an alternative to the likes of Nike or Under Armour.

The designer was not on hand to talk up the collection, but his brother, Jerry Lauren, who oversees menswear, was there to point to the lighter fabrics and to boast about the uptown-downtown range of customers who embrace the brand.

items.content: Tommy Hilfiger also mounted a presentation of brightly colored suits from the brand’s tailored collection — clothes more likely to be seen in Europe than here in the States where the company is more focused on sportswear.

items.blurb: Tommy Hilfiger’s tailored collection for spring 2016. (Neilson Barnard/Getty Images Tommy HIlfiger)
items.fullcaption: Tommy Hilfiger’s tailored collection for spring 2016. (Neilson Barnard/Getty Images Tommy HIlfiger)

items.content: But none had the resonance of John Varvatos, whose collection did more than make a sales pitch for its own worth. It helped to underscore the rising value of this city’s menswear overall.
Men’s Fashion Week celebrates American menswear — but what does Americana look like these days?
Men’s Fashion Week has all the trappings of success. But can the designers deliver?

items.name: Robin Givhan
items.bio: Robin Givhan is a staff writer and the Washington Post fashion critic, covering fashion as a business, as a cultural institution and as pure pleasure.
